newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: ROBECO CAUTIOUS ON SHORT-TERM PROSPECTS.
newsitem.headline: ROBECO CAUTIOUS ON SHORT-TERM PROSPECTS.

text.p: The Robeco group of investment funds said on Wednesday it remained cautious on the short-term prospects for international share markets.

"Many exchanges are now driven by the big flow of liquidities and are thus vulnerable," chairman Piet Korteweg told a news conference on the annual reports of the group's three largest share and fixed income funds.

Board member and head of investment policy Jaap van Duijn said he saw a downward correction on the share markets "of some size" later this year but added that the group's share funds were still almost fully invested and had minimal cash positions.
Korteweg said any correction would be for a rather short period and would be no reason to drastically change the group's longer term policies.
"People always make too much fuss about a correction," he said.
In its 1996 annual report, share investment fund Rolinco was more optimistic on 1997 than its counterpart Robeco , which has a slightly lower risk profile.
But Rolinco manager Gerard de Bruin said he had also adopted a more cautious approach in recent weeks because of falling share prices and interest rate trends.
Rolinco sold some of its investments at high prices earlier this year and now had a small cash position, after starting the year "more than fully invested".
Korteweg saw two, or possibly three scenarios, for the rest of this year.
One was a situation where economic growth turned out to be stronger than expected. This would cause monetary measures to curb growth, which would send share and bond markets down.
But if economic growth lagged behind expectations, interest rates would fall, putting pressure on share markets.
Korteweg said the Robeco group was not sure which of the two scenarios would emerge and even did not exclude a "Goldilocks scenario" where economic growth would be as expected.
The group was therefore flexible in its investment policy and ready to switch between categories if necessary.

Korteweg said yesterday's U.S. interest rate rise was not strictly necessary, given the state of the country's economy and inflation levels, but it was a sign that any possible growth of inflation would be immediately dealt with.
He was doubtful whether more interest rate rises would follow in the United States at short notice.
The Robeco group's total assets under management grew to 81.5 billion guilders in 1996 from 72.4 billion in the previous year. In the first two months of 1997 a further rise to 87 billion was posted.
Shares in Rolinco, which has assets totalling 5.7 billion guilders, rose by 25.2 percent in 1996 and the fund's net asset value grew by 25.4 percent.
Robeco, with total assets of 10.5 billion guilders, posted a net asset value rise of 27.4 percent in 1996 and the fund's share price grew by 28.6 percent.
The Robeco group's fixed income fund Rorento , which manages total assets of 6.7 billion guilders, last year posted a rise in net asset value of 12 percent and its share price rose by 12.2 percent.
Rorento said in its annual report it expected another "handsome" investment result in 1997.
-- Theo Kolker, Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000
